figure_1.title: Figure 1.
figure_1.caption: Skin cancer statistic based on WCRFI, WHO and American Cancer Society (The scheme was prepared based on [4,5,6,7]).

figure_3.title: Figure 3.
figure_3.caption: UV-dependent radiation mutations of tumor suppressor genes p16INK4a and p14ARF and proto-oncogene N-RAS characteristic of skin cancer. (The scheme was prepared based on [53]).

figure_4.title: Figure 4.
figure_4.caption: Molecular mechanisms of the influence of UV radiation on the development and progression of melanoma. (The scheme was prepared based on [52,62]).

figure_5.title: Figure 5.
figure_5.caption: Strategies for the use of nanotechnology in the diagnosis and treatment of skin cancer. Examples of the use of liposomes, metal nanoparticles, and polymer nanoparticles, as well as nanotubes and nanofibrins, indicate the wide spectrum of biological activity of these compounds. The use of nanotechnology clearly increases the efficiency of classical chemotherapy by inter alia improving chemotherapeutic delivery systems, targeted therapies or combination therapies [70,71,72,73].

claims.sentence: The reports of the World Cancer Research Fund International (WCRFI) and the World Health Organization (WHO) on skin cancer statistics and the forecast of future cases are disturbing (Figure 1) [4,5,6,7].
The NMSCs can be distinguished into basal cell carcinoma (carcinoma basocellulare; BCC) and squamous cell carcinoma (carcinoma spinocellulare; SCC); Figure 2.
Notably, UV radiation is among the most potent external mutagenic factors (Figure 3).

Open in a new tab
UV-dependent radiation mutations of tumor suppressor genes p16INK4a and p14ARF and proto-oncogene N-RAS characteristic of skin cancer. (The scheme was prepared based on [53]).The formation of melanomas under the influence of UVR is a complex process involving a series of molecular mechanisms, including mutagenic action, damage to pathways leading to apoptosis, and the promotion of the proliferation of altered, immature cells (Figure 4) [54].
These nanosystems offer unique advantages in targeting tumor cells, enhancing drug delivery, and improving therapeutic efficacy (Figure 5).

The reports of the World Cancer Research Fund International (WCRFI) and the World Health Organization (WHO) on skin cancer statistics and the forecast of future cases are disturbing (Figure 1) [4,5,6,7].
